The holding means preventing the bobbin housing's rotation are positioned on the loop cast-off side, allowing the needle thread loop to expand unhindered until its maximum expansion. Afterward, the loop is pulled back by the thread take-up lever, moving along the bobbin housing's outer surface and then the shoulder's front side face, avoiding contact with the front cam. The slight impediment caused by the spring rod's bending is eliminated by the capsule release device giving the bobbin housing a rotational impulse counter to the hook rotation, ensuring the needle thread loop moves through the thread passage gap without hindrance.

The text describes a method for producing silicon-based nanowires and materials using liquid silane inks in an electrospinning process. The inks consist of a liquid silane, a polymer, an accelerant, and a solvent. The liquid silane can be cyclohexasilane (Si6H12) or other silanes, and the polymer is typically poly(methyl methacrylate) or a polycarbonate. The accelerant, which can be a polyhydropolysilane, speeds up the polymerization of the silane. The solvent is usually toluene, xylene, cyclooctane, 1,2,4-trichlorobenzene, or dichloromethane. The electrospinning process forms continuous fibers that are deposited onto a substrate, which can be a metal foil, carbon fiber matte, or rotating mandrel. The deposited fibers are then transformed through thermal or laser processing to produce polysilane, amorphous silicon, or crystalline silicon materials. The fibers can be coated with a conductive material like graphite or carbon nanotubes for use in composite materials, such as anodes for lithium ion batteries.

The invention is an arrangement for controlling thread tension in a spool creel, which includes a plurality of spool holders each with a brake rotor and an adjustable, tension-responsive braking element. The tensioning lever, coupled to the braking element, is biased by fluid pressure, allowing for centralized control of thread tension for the entire creel or individual spool holders. The biasing arrangement, typically a piston/cylinder assembly, operates in conjunction with the tensioning lever to adjust thread tension based on the weight and tension of the threads. This system enables quick braking of the spools when the warping machine is shut off by increasing the braking force throughout the creel.

The present invention relates to a sewing machine detector that detects the position of a sewing needle and the speed of the sewing machine, which is integral with the drive and control elements of the sewing machine. The detector uses flat, sheet-shaped light shielding discs mounted coaxially to a shaft connected to the sewing machine shaft, which detect the sewing machine speed, needle UP position, needle DOWN position, and thread trimmer timing position. The detector also includes an optical fiber supporter that secures and fixes the optical axes of the light sending and receiving fibers, providing accurate optical axes and a constant and stable operation.

The invention describes a simplified process for the continuous production of high-white degree viscose rayon yarns, involving completion of coagulation, washing with non-alkaline pH water, and drying. This process accelerates the spinning process and reduces space requirements without compromising the yarn's high degree of whiteness, which exceeds common standards.

The text describes a system for deaerating pulp that has been treated with oxygen, aiming to improve the washing process. The deaeration tank, designed to be the same diameter as an oxygen reactor, facilitates the removal of entrained oxygen to prevent foam formation in the washer. The tank features an inlet pipe for introducing the oxygenated pulp, a swirl-inducing design to enhance deaeration, and an outlet for the deaerated pulp. The system also includes a closed tank for steam or oxygen recovery. The deaeration process utilizes the filtrate from the washer as the swirling fluid, optimizing the deaeration efficiency. The system is designed to be compact, with no moving parts, and can operate under atmospheric or low pressure.

The invention relates to composite materials with improved properties, specifically biomimetic tendon-reinforced (BTR) composites that exhibit high out-of-plane stiffness and strength-to-weight ratio. Traditional metallic structures rely on isotropic metal properties, while composite materials offer tailorable properties for enhanced structural performance. The FOMD process, utilizing topology optimization, is employed to design materials optimized for specific functions, such as stiffness, vibration reduction, and noise control. The BTR composite concept involves a structure with stuffer members, tendon elements interconnecting them, and panels bonded to the ends. The stuffer members can be parallel or arranged radially, and the panels can be curved or flat. Tendon elements can be made of various materials, including carbon fibers, nylon, Kevlar, glass fibers, and plant fibers. The invention also includes methods for fabricating these composites, such as using bent-wire tendons and hollow stuffer members, and the potential for using these composites in armor applications.

The invention described in the document is a load-limiting device designed for use in braced frames of structures to dissipate energy during dynamic events, such as earthquakes. The device is capable of undergoing plastic deformation to limit the loads on the structure, thereby preventing extensive damage. It can be easily removed and replaced after a dynamic event. The device can be integrated into various types of braced frames and is constructed of materials that can undergo plastic deformation without undergoing strain-hardening. The device can also be checked for plastic deformation after a dynamic event and replaced if necessary.

The text describes a bedroom cabinet designed for a flophouse facility, optimized for providing individual rooms on a building's floor. It is a unit type cabinet that can be assembled, carried, and installed for various uses, such as workmen's quarters or stadium accommodations. The cabinet has a box shape with a floor area at least equal to a bed's size, allowing users to sit up comfortably. It is designed to be stacked or installed adjacent to each other, maximizing space usage.

The prior art bedroom cabinet, as disclosed in U.S. Pat. No. 4,395,785, has a single layer panel construction, which can lead to reduced strength and sound-proofing issues. The external surfaces are not flat, and protruding boxes for devices like an interphone can reduce the dwelling area.

The present invention aims to overcome these issues by providing a bedroom cabinet with flat external surfaces and a dual construction of an outer casing and an inner casing. This design ensures mechanical strength, allows for the formation of a clearance between the casings, and houses boxes for devices without projecting them within the cabinet or from the outer casing. This effectively utilizes the dwelling area and allows for stacking or adjacent installation of multiple cabinets.

The bedroom cabinet is composed of an upper and lower outer casing, an inner casing, and various panels. The outer casings have flanges at their upper and lower ends, which are brought into abutment when assembled. The inner casing includes a front panel with an opening corresponding to the exit, a back panel with boxes for devices, and side panels with shelves or other features. The clearance between the outer and inner casings can house wirings or other interior electric devices.

A further embodiment of the invention provides spacer members interposed in the clearance between the outer and inner casings. These spacer members have venting grooves, forming an air flow passage around the inner casing for natural ventilation and increasing sound-proofing. The spacer members can vary in strength depending on their position, with the one between the lower surface of the lower outer casing and the bottom panel bearing the most load.

The text also describes the assembly process, including the fitting of the inner casing into the lower outer casing, the registration of the notches of the upper and lower outer casings with the front panel's opening, and the use of a clip member to hold the flanges of the upper and lower outer casings in place. The exit is secured with a hook and an edge frame, and a sheet is provided to cover the mat

The present invention relates to a portable, temporary guard rail support for use in erecting a safety barrier or fence at construction sites. It comprises a flat bottomed base plate, an upright column, guard rail support brackets, a kick board retaining flange, an angular brace, and a safety tie-off ring. The guard rail support allows for the efficient construction and disassembly of safety barriers, reducing the risk of falls and damage to materials. A concrete-filled steel base is also provided for situations where anchoring to a surface is not possible. The system can be used in various construction scenarios, such as around the perimeter of a floor slab during building construction. The guard rail support ensures compliance with safety regulations and provides a durable, reusable solution for temporary safety barriers.

The text describes a pulsed power device and method for enhanced oil recovery (EOR) using a combination of pulsed power electrohydraulic (EH) and electromagnetic (EM) discharges. The device can generate high power outputs for various industrial, chemical, or medical applications, including geophysical exploration, mining, precision demolition, and enhanced oil recovery. The EH mode creates a plasma channel that vaporizes water and generates high pressures and temperatures, while the EM mode produces controlled flux compression for various physical effects. The invention addresses the limitations of direct acoustic stimulation by generating high-frequency EM-induced vibrations that stimulate oil reservoirs at multiple scales, extending the effective range beyond 1000 feet. The method uses coupled EH and EM pulses to stimulate oil flow and increase ultimate recovery. The device can be customized for specific reservoir properties and frequencies, and can be directed using a range of focusing and shaping devices. The electrodes are improved to withstand pulse discharges, and the fluids produced from the wellbore are separated into their components for further processing.

The text describes a splice for connecting soil reinforcing elements to extend their length, which is useful in retaining wall structures. The splice includes wave plates with transverse protrusions to receive and seat the transverse wires of the soil reinforcing elements, and a connective device to couple the plates together, securing the wires in place.

The text describes a novel plow blade design for delivering services like telephone, television, natural gas, electricity, and drainage through underground trenches. This design aims to reduce the power needed to pull the plow by injecting water to lubricate the blade and chute, minimizing friction. The blade is constructed using basic manufacturing processes, allowing efficient production and easy modification. It includes a fluid tube that can be adjusted for length and number of leading edge sections, enabling customization for specific jobs. An alternative embodiment uses a manifold to control fluid injection rates and locations. Another embodiment positions the fluid tube on the rear side of the blade, protected by plates, and connects it to a bottom end section with a void for fluid flow. The design allows for fluid to exit the blade through gaps between stitch welds or a manifold, optimizing lubrication and reducing power requirements.

The text describes a building system, particularly focusing on stucco type cavity wall construction techniques. It addresses the limitation in New Zealand where exterior panels defined in situ in plaster material are restricted to a height of about 2.4 meters high and 4 meters wide due to building regulations. The invention aims to provide a building system that allows for panels greater than 2.4 meters in height and 4 meters in width without the need for movement control joints. This system is designed to comply with both the plaster code NZS4251 and the building code NZS3604, offering a useful choice for the public. The system includes a frame or substructure with studs, battens, inner and outer meshes, and plaster matrix applied in multiple layers to achieve the desired dimensions and rigidity.

The text describes a safe construction with a valuables receiving chamber, featuring a steel door that is secured in place using a set of inwardly extending ledges and grooves. The door is engaged with the ledges and grooves, with one edge inserted at an angle into a deeper groove while the other edge pivots towards a ledge, allowing the door to be laterally displaced until it is seated in the shallower groove. The door also includes a lock assembly with a latch bolt engaging a detent and reinforcing bolts on both sides of the lock bolt to prevent forceful intrusion.

<summary>
The text describes various embodiments of geological formation pressure sensing systems designed to accurately measure pressures at desired depths without being influenced by pressures in the formation above or below the measuring apparatus. These systems include a conduit fitted with a filter at its bottom end, which is cemented into a borehole at the desired location. The conduit is pressurized with fluid to clear the filter of cement grout and establish a fluid connection between the formation and the filter. In some embodiments, a hydrofracture process is used once the grout has set to ensure connectivity. The pressure transducer is installed at the desired depth, and its input is isolated to the formation pressures at that depth, allowing for accurate measurement without interference from other pressures in the borehole. The systems are adaptable for use in various reservoir types and can be serviced or relocated as needed. The text also outlines methods for monitoring fluid pressure in a subterranean formation, including forming a borehole, placing a conduit with a non-return valve, and filling the borehole with cementitious material to establish a fluid connection to the formation. The pressure sensing device is then coupled to the formation fluid pressure within the conduit to measure the fluid pressure at the desired depth.
</summary>

The invention relates to a jointing structure for vehicle travel paths and the like, which includes an expansion function, and a method for mounting an elastic member. This structure is particularly useful for new transit systems, monorails, and road bridges. The structure comprises more than one step provided face to face at the ends of a traveling path with an expansion gap, more than one elastic member mounted inside the steps, and a joint block mounted across the expansion gap. The elastic members are designed to deform horizontally to absorb expansion or contraction caused by temperature changes, while the joint block prevents tire fall-in or stuck-in situations. The invention also includes a method for mounting the elastic members, which involves joining them across the expansion gap and fixing one side to the step, then deforming the member towards the bridge girder axis before fixing the other side. The elastic members are designed to be free of deformation when the bridge girder length reaches a median temperature, ensuring smooth and safe vehicle travel.

The invention relates to an enclosed floor track system for use in a fluid treatment chamber, particularly for moving wheeled trucks into and out of the chamber without contaminating the sanitary environment. The system prevents brine solution from entering the wheel channel area and becoming contaminated by the truck wheels. In one embodiment, the enclosed track includes a wheel channel above the fluid level on the floor, with opposed sidewalls and a cover plate overlying the top of the channel. The vertical space between the shorter sidewall and the cover plate accommodates the axle structure connecting the truck frame to the wheel. In another embodiment, the sidewalls of the wheel channel extend upwardly beyond the top of the wheel structure and include inflatable elastomer seals at the top edges. These seals are hose-like and attached along the length of the sidewall top edges to enclose around the hand truck wheel struts and prevent entry of the brine solution into the guide track. When inflated, the elastomer strips form a seal around the wheel struts, as well as against itself along the remaining length of the floor track. The system allows for the use of wheeled hand trucks in a fluid treatment center while preventing the wheels or other support structure from contaminating the treatment fluid.

The text describes a lock device designed for preventing a work machine, such as a boom in a backhoe, from being rotated downward due to its own weight. The device includes an engaging member (lock plate) and an engaged member (lock pin) that interact to lock and unlock the work machine. The lock plate can be manually moved to either a lock or release position, with the lock position being maintained even when the boom is rotated between its highest and lowest positions. This design simplifies the lock mechanism and reduces the risk of damage to the engaging and engaged members.

The invention is a swimming pool vacuum cleaner with a flexible platform that allows the central, vacuum portion to be easily adjusted relative to the pool bottom. This adjustment enables precise regulation of suction efficiency during the cleaning operation. The adjustment mechanisms are conveniently located on the top of the vacuum head and can be quickly operated by hand without the need for hand tools. The device can be easily retrofitted to certain existing pool cleaning devices, enhancing their suction regulation capabilities.

The text describes an invention for retrieving wear bushings used in oil well drilling. The apparatus includes a sub-unit that can be threaded onto a drill string between sections of pipe, with a retriever section that slides onto the sub-unit. The retriever section has protruding members that align with slots in the wear bushing to lock it in place for retrieval. The design allows for vertical play in the retriever section, preventing damage from the weight of the drill string if the alignment is not perfect. An alternative embodiment uses threading to engage the wear bushing for retrieval.

The invention pertains to a downhole vibratory tool designed to dislodge a stuck object, or "fish," from a wellbore. Vibratory tools are used to apply forces to the fish to free it from the wellbore. The tool described in the document is capable of allowing a wireline or other tools to pass through it when not in vibratory mode, by having an annular dump valve that keeps the central passage clear. This design allows for wireline access through the tool body without the need to remove the tool. The tool features modular stacked piston units to deliver additional power per stroke, enhancing the force applied to the fish. The tool can be operated to deliver high amplitude, low frequency oscillating forces to the fish without impacts, or with impacts depending on the operation. The design avoids slamming parts against seats, reduces fatigue on moving parts, and allows for larger, more durable components. The tool can be configured to tolerate continued downward movement of the mandrel to dissipate its momentum after the dump valve opens. The tool can be run to apply up oscillating forces with or without impacts, depending on the operation by rig personnel. The design also includes a retrievable plug that can be dropped onto a seat to close off a passage, allowing the tool to be activated. The tool can be used in various applications, including stimulation and fishing operations, and can rely on a single valve for operation.

The present invention pertains to a precast concrete retaining wall system used alongside highways and railways. It addresses the limitations of conventional retaining walls, particularly in terms of height and stability. The system comprises a precast, substantially solid, rectangular or trapezoidal base and a face panel with an integral counterfort. The counterfort extends from the rear side of the face panel, providing support and reducing the pressure at the toe of the wall. The face panel and counterfort are set upright on the base with a connection joining them together, eliminating the need for temporary shoring. The system allows for taller walls and shorter bases by pre-manufacturing parts, saving on installation and transportation costs. The components can vary in size, making the system flexible and customizable. The invention also includes options for enhancing stability, such as using H-piles or a cast-in-place impact barrier.

The text describes an improved down hole heating system designed for oil and gas wells to increase flow rates, particularly when flow is impeded by high viscosity or paraffin blockage. The system addresses two primary shortcomings of conventional heating units: inadequate protection for electrical components from chemical or physical attack and ineffective heat focus in the production zone. It includes a heat insulating packer, perforated tubing, a stainless steel tubing collar, and a heating unit with electrical resistance type heater rods. The heating unit is designed to prevent unit invasion by down hole fluids, causing physical damage or electrical shortages, and focuses heat in the production zone to promote flow to the production tubing.

The invention relates to a simply and efficiently operable mechanism for installing and removing objects in wells, particularly those that might be stuck or lost within a well bore. It is specifically designed to improve the connection of a pull tool to a down hole object or "fish" and to enable simple and effective disconnection if desired. The mechanism is adaptable for use in drilling operations, well servicing, and for controlling down hole devices positioned within casing and tubing strings. It features an external pull tool or overshot that can be run into the well casing or bore for establishing a mechanical connection with an object to be removed. The tool structure consists of an outer tubular body with an inner body disposed in a movable relation. Telescoping movement of the inner and outer body structures allows the tool to selectively move into gripping relationship with the object. The tool is secured by a catch mechanism with a locking and unlocking position, depending on the relative positions of the inner and outer body structures. The mechanism allows for easy disconnection by simply moving the wire line controlled pulling tool in a downward and then upward direction.

The text describes a method for manufacturing composed stave floors, focusing on improving the sight substrate's thickness to at least 4mm and the base substrate's thickness to at least 12mm. This is combined with glue and multidirectional holding means, such as dendrites, adhesion, and reinforcement, to prevent displacement and deformation. The method aims to preserve the floor's physical, aesthetic, and functional properties, provide a floor with a longer useful life, and allow for corrective maintenance. The use of improved bonding means ensures the sheets are fixed firmly without changing dimensions. The text also mentions the use of site-preferred glazes, such as aluminum oxide, to enhance the floor's durability and appearance. The text includes figures and detailed descriptions of the floor's components and the manufacturing process.

The invention described in the text is a ladder attachment designed to improve lateral stability, prevent damage to work surfaces, and prevent the ladder from slipping or sliding. It features a brace with a flange that encircles a ladder rung, a U-bolt, and a resilient pad assembly that can be pivotally connected to the brace. This setup allows the ladder to have better contact with the work surface, preventing defacement, and improving stability, especially when straddling corners. The attachment is adjustable and can be used on both sides of the ladder, enhancing safety and efficiency during various tasks.

The text describes a fastener assembly and method for making it, which includes a row of fasteners arranged parallel to each other and a plastic collation system molded onto the fasteners. The collation system has a collar that captures the fastener shank and a connecting portion between adjacent fasteners. The plastic is formulated from an adhesive polymer like polyolefin or epoxy, and the fasteners are preheated before molding the plastic. The assembly can be configured to minimize debris generation when the fastener is driven into a substrate. This is achieved by preferentially weakening the connecting portion at a desired location, influencing its separation from the collar. The assembly can also include a rib that extends less than the axial length of the collar, and the rib can have a width greater than the collar width. The assembly can be configured with the connecting portion including a cruciform-shaped bridge and rib, with the rib being tapered. The assembly can also include upper and lower collations parallel to and spaced from each other, with the lower collation being narrower than the upper collation. The fasteners can have a penetration expanding portion or deformations on the shank to further enhance penetration and reduce debris generation.

The invention is a nozzle for applying sealants, particularly useful in industries like aviation, automotive, naval, railway, and robotics. It features a bell-shaped tip and an injection button with a special design for precise sealant application, especially for encapsulating rivets and screws. The button has channels and orifices to guide the sealant around the rivets and nuts. The nozzle is made of plastic, preferably polypropylene, and can be connected to most cartridges or machines containing sealant. It allows for both manual and automated sealant injection processes. The bell-shaped section is designed to completely cover rivets or nuts with sealing material. The injection button, when coupled to the bell-shaped section, enables precise sealing operations, directing the flow of sealant to specific areas like chamfers or walls of orifices. The application of sealant with this nozzle ensures a perfect seal from air and oxidizing liquids, crucial for pressurization and longevity in various industries. Once sealing operations are completed, the nozzle can be repurposed for applying sealing cords, filler sealant, or safety cords to ensure full sealing of fuel tanks and other elements. This invention simplifies sealing work, saving time and labor, and enhancing the quality of sealant application.

The text describes a position sensor that includes a waveform generator and an error correction generator. The waveform generator receives an unconditioned sensing signal from a transducer and modifies it based on an error correction signal. The error correction generator, which includes a comparator, controller, and signal processor, removes unwanted power and static signals from the sensing signal. The sensor is designed to minimize energy usage and improve reliability, making it suitable for multiplexing with other sensors. The sensor's output is conditioned to remove static signals and errors, ensuring accurate position information is transmitted to a remote monitoring system via two wires.

The text describes a variable, desmodromic valve actuation system for internal combustion engines, which eliminates the need for springs and provides precise control over valve port openness. This system uses a rotating cam and translating means to interact with a second controllable actuating means that controls valve position, allowing for substantially infinitely variable displacement and percentage opening of the valve ports. The system is designed to improve fuel efficiency and engine performance by controlling the amount of air/gas mixture entering each piston and enabling the closure of any number of cylinders while the engine is operating. The invention also includes computer control of the valves to optimize engine performance based on vehicle speed and conditions.

The text describes a light member for aquariums that includes a housing with a top side facing away from the aquarium and a bottom side facing the aquarium's interior. The light member has a lighting control region on the bottom side with a first control channel for white light, a second control channel for blue light, and a neutral channel. The light member also features a switch to control the first control channel, allowing users to adjust the color temperature of the emitted light.

The text describes a cooled flow deflection apparatus for high-temperature fluid-flow machines, such as gas turbines, aiming to improve upon existing designs. The apparatus, particularly stator or rotor blades, uses internal cooling channels to manage high temperatures. Traditionally, these channels and their separating walls are cast together, leading to several disadvantages. The invention proposes constructing the separating walls as separate inserts that are inserted into the apparatus after casting, offering several advantages:

1. Reduces material in the transitional region between hot-gas walls and separating walls, minimizing heat transfer and cooling air consumption.
2. Eliminates thermal stresses between the separating walls and hot-gas walls.
3. Reduces blade weight and centrifugal force stresses, especially in rotating blades.
4. Simplifies casting processes and reduces scrap.
5. Allows for easier adjustment of the cooling system by replacing inserts.
6. Inserts can be made of metal or non-metal materials, such as ceramics or composites.
7. Integrally formed holders in the interior of the flow deflection apparatus facilitate secure seating of the inserts.
8. Inserts can be connected to the apparatus by integral material joints, such as soldering or welding, for added security.
9. The invention is particularly advantageous for gas turbine blades, offering significant simplifications in design and production.

The text describes a system and method for controlling the operation of a fuel delivery system for a vehicle, allowing for both automatic and manual control. The system uses a control unit to process signals from the accelerator pedal and throttle valve position, providing a control signal to a DC motor or stepper motor to automatically set the throttle position for optimal vehicle performance. The system also allows for manual control by connecting the accelerator pedal directly to the throttle valve, ensuring a smooth transition between automatic and manual control modes without causing the vehicle to lurch or stall.

The text describes a waste fuel burner designed to efficiently combust particulate-laden gases or waste fuels like wood waste, emitting minimal particulate matter and slag. The burner forms a conical pile of waste fuel with preheated underfire air blowing up through it, drying and gasifying the fuel. Volatile gases are partially oxidized by additional swirl air introduced tangentially into a primary combustion chamber, maintaining a temperature below the melting point of ash and dirt to prevent slag formation. The swirl air also separates particulate matter, which is then further combusted in a secondary chamber with secondary combustion air. The burner is self-regulating, easy to control, and can handle wet wood of 70% moisture content. It is adaptable for various fuels and can be used in boilers or other industrial applications. The design includes features like a flame holder to separate particulate matter and a pressure isolator to prevent particulate from entering the secondary chamber. The burner operates at lower excess air levels than conventional systems, reducing energy waste and improving efficiency. It also allows for quick adjustments in fuel volume and air supply, improving response time to meet varying demands. The burner minimizes clinker and slag formation, requiring infrequent cleaning, and extends the life of the refractory lining by keeping temperatures below 1200°F.

The text describes an evaporative refrigeration system that efficiently cools air without adding water vapor, using a heat exchanger to separate dry and wet sides. The system draws major portions of the working air (used for the wet side) from the room to be cooled, as it has a lower wet bulb temperature than fresh air. The major portion of the useful air, which passes through the dry side, is fresh air. The system utilizes an array of vertically directed hollow elongated tubular members for the heat exchanger, with water flowing downwardly along the inner surfaces and return air flowing countercurrently for evaporation. The text also discusses variations in operation, such as recirculating return air and bypassing cooled air, to achieve different cooling rates and energy costs. The system is designed to maximize cooling efficiency at low energy costs, with specific construction details provided for the heat exchanger and its components. A hybrid system combining evaporative cooling with vapor compression refrigeration is also described, which can provide lower temperatures but at higher energy levels.

The text describes a fluid pump with two or more pump heads arranged in series for pumping fluids at high volumetric flow rates and pressures. The pump heads contain impellers that move fluid through conduits, with the fluid from multiple conduits combining into a single flow before exiting the pump head. The pump heads are connected through a drive structure that drives the impellers. The pump can be powered by a single motor and can be mounted on various support structures like a wheeled boom, hitching assembly, or trailer for use in animal husbandry operations. The pump is designed to handle solid material in the fluid, making it suitable for pumping liquid manure. The pump can be modular, allowing for the addition of more pump heads to increase operating pressure.

The text discusses an engine compression release brake system designed for engines with fewer than all cylinders having brakes. This system aims to reduce engine components, improving overall robustness. It includes an engine housing defining multiple cylinders, with brakes attached to a portion of these cylinders, less than all. The method involves attaching brakes to a selected number of cylinders and operating them in a braking mode when required. The engine compression release brake is operably coupled to a cam actuated exhaust valve. The system utilizes a hydraulic system for engine braking, with components like a low pressure reservoir, high pressure pump, and electronic control module for managing the operation. The engine's cylinders undergo typical intake, compression, and exhaust strokes, with the braking process activated during the compression stroke for selected cylinders. The brake system includes a solenoid actuator, a valve member, and a spool valve for controlling the flow of hydraulic fluid. The brake is activated by electronic control module during the compression stroke to release engine compression, allowing air to be vented through the exhaust valve. The brake is deactivated after providing the desired braking, resetting the system for the next cycle.

The text discusses an innovative mounting link assembly designed for use between an engine and an auxiliary gearbox in aircraft gas turbine engines. This assembly includes a male link, a female link, and a pin. The male and female links allow for translation relative to each other, forming a radial interface that dampens this motion. The pin, which is designed to shear under extreme loads, selectively retains the male and female links. This design allows the gearbox to withstand blade-off events without transmitting potentially destructive loads to the engine, while also preventing the gearbox from detaching. The use of this mounting link assembly reduces the need for all components to withstand extreme loads, potentially decreasing weight and material usage.

The invention described in the document relates to archery equipment, specifically to an improved system for attaching arrow points and nocks to shafts and balancing the shafts. The point cap system, which includes a small, lightweight point cap and a balance pin, addresses the shortcomings of prior art by providing adjustable weight and balance, reducing material and weight, and preventing dirt entry when arrow points are removed. The balance pin allows for adjustable weight to achieve perfect balance, and the point cap system is designed to work with unidirectional fiber reinforced shafts, encapsulating the end of the shaft with a material that has nearly the same strength properties in all directions.

The invention described in the document is a Small Arms Firing Effect Simulator (SAFES) designed to simulate the sound and flash of small arms fire for military training purposes. It utilizes a low-cost plastic housing containing a metal/oxidizer pyrotechnic and an electrical ignition system. The SAFES can be inserted into a weapon via the magazine breech, producing sound and flash through the electrical ignition of the pyrotechnic in a confined space, vented through the weapon's ejection port. The electrical control circuitry allows for automatic and semi-automatic fire, interfacing with the weapon's trigger and bolt. The circuitry includes components like a bolt interface, trigger interface, oscillator control, and firing control, which work together to simulate the firing of live rounds. The SAFES is designed to provide a realistic simulation of small arms fire noise and flash, offering an inexpensive and reliable means for realistic training without the use of live ammunition. The system is packaged to resemble the magazine clip of an M16 rifle, enhancing its realism.

The text describes an air intake device for an internal combustion engine designed to enhance engine performance and reduce noise. It utilizes a tank with a volume extending along the intake tube, a valve in an interconnecting portion between the tank and the intake passage, and valve activating means responsive to engine load. The device aims to improve volumetric efficiency by optimizing the dynamic effects of air flow. It is noted that shortening the air inlet pipe upstream of the air cleaner enhances dynamic effects but increases noise. The invention proposes an intake device with a first pipe having a larger cross-sectional area than the intake passage and a second pipe with a smaller cross-sectional area, located closer to the air cleaner. This configuration aims to improve engine performance while reducing noise. The control valve, actuated by a vacuum diaphragm actuator, is positioned in the first pipe. The valve's operation is controlled by a controller based on engine load conditions, with the vacuum source connected to the intake manifold. The text also discusses the relationship between the valve's operation and engine speed, volumetric efficiency, and noise reduction.

The invention is a two-part bracket for mounting speakers or other equipment to poles, flat surfaces, or structures. It allows for simple mounting by connecting the two parts of the bracket together. The bracket assembly consists of a stationary bracket and an adjustable bracket. The adjustable bracket is attached to the equipment to be mounted, while the stationary bracket is mounted on the surface or pole. The adjustable bracket is then positioned on the stationary bracket, and the two parts snap together temporarily without tools or hardware. Axel screws are inserted through the adjustable bracket into the stationary bracket to form a hinge and secure the assembly. The bracket is designed for one person to install heavy items without needing to support the weight of the object and handle attachment hardware simultaneously. The bracket assembly includes components that are resistant to weather, wind, and vibration, making it suitable for outdoor use. The bracket can be used on poles, walls, or other surfaces, and includes pole adapters for mounting on poles. A speaker mounting bracket can be attached to the adjustable bracket to mount a loudspeaker using the assembly.

The present disclosure relates to a combustion apparatus, particularly a burner that can be part of a system with interchangeable or modular heat utilizing appliances. The goal is to optimize efficiency and limit unburned fuel emissions while providing a clean-burning solution suitable for diverse appliances like cooking grills, cooktops, food smoking apparatus, space heaters, and pyrolyzers. The burner features a combustion chamber enclosed by an outer wall with a fuel holder, allowing air to flow through and around the fuel holder for primary and secondary combustion. A shroud surrounds the outer wall, establishing a flow path for tertiary combustion air and providing an external surface that is cool enough to avoid burns. The burner includes legs to hold it above ground level and a pivotally coupled ash pan. A perforate food grate is also pivotally coupled, movable between a deployed position above the flame and a stowed position to the side of the combustion chamber. A cover is pivotally coupled to the burner, enabling the combustion chamber to be closed to prevent accidental ingress of items or exposure to heat and exhaust fumes. The burner has manual couplings for removably attaching modular heat utilizing appliances, including closed and open cookers, a food smoker, a space heater, and a pyrolyzer. The nature of the disclosed concepts is further explained through various figures and detailed descriptions.

The text discusses the challenges in cooling and ignition systems for rotary internal combustion engines, particularly focusing on the cooling of the housing and the arrangement of spark plugs. It highlights the issues with the in-line arrangement of spark plugs, which disrupts the flow of cooling fluid, collects vapor films, and hinders heat extraction. The invention described aims to improve cooling characteristics and reduce the possibility of structural failure by providing an ignition and cooling system combination that maintains efficient combustion. The housing structure facilitates circumferential cooling flow while permitting the intrusion of spark plug bosses, minimizing thermal distortion, especially in the zone surrounding the spark plug bosses. The invention employs staggered spark plug bosses, offset but symmetrically oppositely oriented about a centerplane of the flow, to promote relatively close in-line arrangement of the spark plug terminals, improve coolant performance, and increase the heat transfer coefficient of the cooling circuit by at least 20% over prior art capabilities.

The present invention is a method for minimizing flow disturbance caused by the closing and reopening of turbine control valves during periodic operational testing. It uses control valve positions as feedback to maintain constant total mass flow through several parallel turbine inlet flow control valves, thus keeping steam generator pressure constant and unaffected during testing. The method calculates total mass flow as a function of control valve position and determines the flow difference between N and N-1 valves when one valve is closed for testing. This difference is applied to the total flow demand for the remaining valves to minimize flow disturbance. The system uses a test compensation circuit that includes a test compensation array, sample and hold circuit, multiplier circuit, and divider circuit to adjust the flow through the control valves. The method was validated through a mathematical model and real-time simulation, showing a 95% reduction in turbine inlet main steam pressure excursion during valve testing with the flow compensation function compared to without it.

The invention relates to a mixing valve for combining fluids from two separate sources into one mixture, specifically for an aircraft cleaning apparatus. The valve allows for the adjustment of the mixture ratio between 0% inlet A fluid, 100% inlet B fluid to 100% inlet A fluid, 0% inlet B fluid, providing users with control over the strength of the cleaning solution.

The text describes a method and arrangement for compressing gas in a compressor station for a gas pipeline, particularly in permanent frost areas. The method involves compressing gas delivered in the pipeline to a higher pressure, cooling it by heat exchange, and then feeding it back to the pipeline with a lower exit temperature and increased exit pressure. The arrangement includes a compressor, heat exchanger, and control units. The invention proposes compressing the gas to an excess pressure above the desired exit pressure, cooling it by heat exchange, and then expanding it to the desired exit pressure. This reduces the required investments and operation risks compared to conventional re-cooling plants. The method utilizes the cooling effect of expanding compressed gas to a lower pressure. The arrangement includes a compressor, heat exchanger, and control units for operating the compressor and valves. The invention is particularly useful in areas with permanent frost, where ground thawing must be prevented to avoid mechanical stresses on the pipeline. The method and arrangement are designed to ensure the required exit temperature and pressure for the compressed gas, while minimizing energy consumption and investment costs.

The text describes an innovative system for mounting cooling fans to enclosures without the use of traditional fasteners, aiming to reduce costs in various applications including automotive, computer, and electronic instrumentation. The system involves a cooling fan assembly with a motor, fan blade, and motor control components, which is designed to be mounted onto a panel using a motor carrier with resilient legs. The legs are inserted into recessed openings on the panel, and through a series of steps involving loading, compressing, rotating, and further rotating, the fan assembly is securely mounted onto the panel without the need for additional fasteners. This design not only reduces costs but also enhances the stability and noise reduction of the fan assembly in its operational environment.

The text discusses the need for advanced lightweight and stiff composite materials in spacecraft structures to meet weight efficiency requirements for space missions. These materials, however, lack inherent damping or vibration dissipation, leading to potentially high vibration levels that can compromise instrument functionality. The text highlights the importance of precision kinematic mounts (KM) in this context, noting their limited damping capabilities. It mentions that 14% of spacecraft launches through 1984 suffered vibration/shock related failures, with 50% resulting in catastrophic mission loss. The document then introduces the concept of modifying graphite structures to reduce overall vibration response, but notes that this may not be sufficient. It outlines the need for additional vibration reduction techniques for instruments. The invention described in the text aims to provide kinematic mounts with novel damping features to protect instruments from flight loads. These mounts incorporate vibration damping materials into the mounts to dissipate high energy disturbances. The modifications preserve the fundamental features of strength, stiffness, and kinematic features. Two embodiments of the damper design are presented, one using a spherical damper and the other a cylindrical slot damper. The text also discusses the importance of selecting appropriate viscoelastic materials with frequency-dependent properties for damping during flight. Finally, it mentions the potential for alternative damped KM designs, such as truss structures or a set of three damped versions of the mount configuration, and the benefits of these designs, including uncoupling the suspension vibration modes for improved performance.

The text describes an improved oil shear type clutch unit designed for large power transmission requirements, particularly for aircraft catapult systems. The clutch unit features separate pistons for each set of clutch disc segments, which minimizes residual drag. It also utilizes hydraulic fluid for retracting the plate actuating means and as a coolant for the clutch discs. The clutch discs are segmented, allowing for easy replacement of individual segments without disassembling the entire mechanism. This design enhances cooling, torque control, and reduces disc friction, making it suitable for high-power applications like aircraft catapults.

The text describes an internal combustion engine that uses multiple cylinders to capture and utilize more of the energy generated during combustion. The engine includes a combustion cylinder that produces exhaust gas, which is then expanded in one or more downstream expansion cylinders. Water is injected into the system to increase the energy output and efficiency. The expansion cylinders are designed to have a large surface area and volume to lower the temperature of the exhaust gas, potentially eliminating the need for a radiator. Additionally, the system incorporates catalytic materials to convert impurities in the exhaust gases within the engine itself, and a water recovery system to recycle water used in the expansion process.

The text describes a method for fabricating coated steel plates intended for welding and heat treatment to produce parts with good mechanical and corrosion resistance. The process involves coating a steel substrate with an aluminum alloy, then removing a portion of the aluminum alloy layer at the periphery of the plate. This prevents the formation of intermetallic areas during welding, which can reduce the deformability of the joint. The method also ensures good corrosion resistance after heat treatment. The steel composition is tailored to achieve desired mechanical properties, such as tensile strength, and the microstructure can be martensitic, bainitic, or bainitic-martensitic. The text also outlines a method for removing the aluminum alloy layer using brushing or a laser beam, and provides an example of the process. The resulting plates, blanks, or parts have improved ductility and corrosion resistance, making them suitable for use in automotive components like bumpers, door reinforcements, and roof reinforcements.

The present invention is a Supervisory Control And Data Acquisition (SCADA) remote control system for a mobile structure that recovers energy from severe weather patterns. It includes an algorithm that optimizes efficiency by accounting for data from weather observations and sensors on the mobile structure, relating these data points to performance models for the mobile structure. The system is designed for navigation and automatic operation of a mobile energy recovery system, such as a sailing vessel optimized to reduce drag while responding to wind and water velocity vectors. The SCADA system gathers data through various means, including GPS systems, weather satellite systems, and geographic and weather data resources. The system includes computer servers that run secure software applications for remote human interaction and mission critical navigation plans. The invention is not limited to the referenced Turbine-Integrated Hydrofoil system and applies to any mobile structure that exploits energy from weather patterns. The system enables automatic tracking of hazardous environmental conditions, making manned operation undesirable and rendering energy exploitation systems unrealizable without the present invention.

The invention relates to a rolling body guide cage produced from a sheet metal material using forming production steps, featuring at least one ring element and several guide structures arranged in the circumferential direction to guide rolling bodies. The cage is made from flat material ring segments joined and welded together in a production step before forming. This reduces production costs and waste, especially for cages with large internal diameters. The ring segments are cut from a sheet metal strip, forming 120° segments that require only three weld points for assembly. The segments are joined through positive engagement and undercut geometries, ensuring adequate coupling and minimizing weld seam length. The method includes punching out the segments, welding them, and optionally contouring or calibrating the segments after welding.

<summary>
The text describes a system and methods for obtaining, processing, and transmitting information related to providing customer service at a customer service location. It involves a technician input device, a technician server, and a global positioning satellite system (GPS) to acquire latitude and longitude coordinates associated with the customer service location. The system also includes a dispatch system, an address guide system, and a customer records system to manage and update information related to service issues and customer records. The GPS system is used to track, dispatch, and monitor service technicians and their input devices at multiple customer service locations. The system allows for the generation of directions for a service technician traveling between customer service locations, reducing the possibility of error in locating a service location and enhancing customer service response time. The text also mentions the use of computer-readable media for storing and transmitting data. The system aims to improve customer service by providing accurate and specific information about service locations, thus reducing response time and potentially preventing customer loss due to delayed or missed commitments.
</summary>

The text describes a system for compensating electromagnetic interfering fields, particularly magnetic fields, using two real triaxial magnetic field sensors, three pairs of compensation coils, and a digital processor. The system aims to compensate both homogeneous and inhomogeneous magnetic fields. It includes a control unit designed as a Digital Signal Processor (DSP) or Field Programmable Gate Array (FPGA). The six output signals from the two sensors are combined to create three output signals of a virtual sensor through a defined averaging process. This virtual sensor output is used as input for independent control loops that generate modified signals. These signals are then transformed into control signals for the six coils. The system can handle inhomogeneous fields by using a single actuator coil instead of a pair of Helmholtz coils. It also addresses the issue of feedback between two compensation systems placed close to each other by incorporating a cross-coupling matrix. The control system is flexible, allowing for broadband, selective frequency range, or selective frequency control algorithms.

The text describes a method for investigating a sample derived from a biological source using coherent anti-Stokes Raman scattering (CARS) microscopy. The method involves furnishing at least one resonance site by means of a bioorthogonal reaction of an intrinsic chemical structure of the sample with at least one reaction partner. Bioorthogonal reactions are chemical reactions that can proceed in living systems without interfering with natural processes. The method allows for the introduction of resonance sites into a sample that may not naturally possess them, enabling improved visualization and specificity in CARS microscopy. The text also discusses the use of bioorthogonal reactions in combination with CARS microscopy to increase specificity and scattering cross-section, as well as the potential for reproducible counter-staining of the non-resonant background. The text provides an overview of the method, including its application in CARS microscopy, and references to relevant literature and figures.

The invention provides a system for assessing radiation therapy segmentations by comparing different segmentations of the same structure in a patient, using electronic files that describe the segmentations in the form of three-dimensional surfaces. The system converts these files into volume models, compares them to identify common, missing, and extra volume elements, and outputs a measure of conformance between the segmentations based on a metric method that evaluates the number of missing and extra elements.

The text describes an invention that accelerates the execution of floating point operations in data processing systems. It introduces techniques to speed up the effective subtraction operation by determining the difference between subsets of the operand exponent arguments before calculating the complete difference. This allows initiating the subtraction of operand fractions based on the subset difference, which can lead to the correct final fraction result when the complete difference is determined to be incorrect. The invention uses the differences between the complete and subset operand exponent arguments to identify the correct final fraction result, thereby reducing the time required for the effective subtraction operation. The apparatus implementing the invention includes units for determining the difference between the complete and subset operand exponent arguments, as well as for performing the final fraction result calculation.

The text describes a method and system for tracking and collecting medical specimens, such as blood, from patients in a hospital setting. The system uses a computer to store and manage patient and specimen information, including unique machine-readable codes on patient ID bands, specimen collection orders, and specimen containers. The method involves storing patient, order, and specimen-taker codes in a relational manner within the computer's storage. It ensures that the correct specimen is collected from the right patient by verifying the codes match before allowing the collection process to proceed. The system also includes checking the expiration date of specimen containers and generating alerts if they are out-of-date. The method aims to reduce mislabeling errors and improve patient safety by providing a failsafe process for specimen collection. The system can be implemented using standalone or networked computers, and it is not limited to blood specimens but can be used for any type of biological specimen.

The invention is a voice-activated distance measuring device designed for golfers and other sports enthusiasts. It utilizes voice recognition technology and GPS to provide verbal information on the golf course, such as distance to the pin, green size, and pin placement. The device can be integrated into various portable devices, including headgear like hats or visors, and can also incorporate distance measuring technologies like infrared, optics, or Doppler acoustics. It can predict golf strategy, club selection, and other needs based on user input and historical data. The device features a bone conductance vibration sensor for improved voice recognition, and can be expanded with additional features like a communications method for data transfer to a personal computer. The device's main printed circuit board assembly is designed to fit within a hat's brim, with components like a battery, transducer, and connectors integrated into the design. Bluetooth technology is utilized for data transfers, audio server/client functions, short-range audio communications, and as a remote GPS. The device also allows users to record geographic coordinates of a golf course, which can be shared and used for various purposes, including calculating distances and aiding in course maintenance or map production.

The text describes a system and method for checking design rules in semiconductor integrated circuits (ICs) that contain both logic and memory components. The system addresses the issue of false errors caused by design rule checking tools examining regions not subject to the same rules. It achieves this by customizing design rules for different types of regions, such as logic, Bordered Single Port (BDSP) SRAM, Borderless Single Port (BLSP) SRAM, Dual Port (DP) SRAM, and ROM, based on modifying standard logic rules to accommodate more liberal memory-based parameters. The method involves creating customized design rule check command files that apply the right set of rules to the right regions of the mask pattern data. This ensures accurate resolution of design rules for systems on chip that use a mix of logic and memory circuitry. The system and method eliminate the need for manual checking and reduce the possibility of false errors, thus expediting the design development cycle.

The invention pertains to the use of waveguide holograms for illuminating objects with specific requirements, such as display holograms or spatial light modulators. Thin substrate waveguides, characterized by their relationship between the width of an incident laser beam and the waveguide's thickness, are used to provide improved, controlled illumination. These waveguides can compensate for non-uniformity in the diffracted wavefront and are particularly useful for illuminating demanding objects, offering high diffraction efficiencies and minimizing stray light.

The text describes a method and apparatus for testing squirrel cage rotors in dynamoelectric machines, such as electric motors and generators. The apparatus includes a test head for rotating the rotor in a static magnetic field and voltage sensing means for generating a voltage signal in response to the rotor's magnetic flux variations. Current sensing means measures the alternating current used to magnetize the rotor, and processing means calculates the rotor's resistance and reactance. Skew sensing means measures the effective electrical skew of the rotor, and processing means determines the skew. The apparatus provides automatic pass/fail determinations and detailed statistical analysis of measurement results. The test head has a core structure similar to a conventional dynamoelectric machine stator, with primary windings for exciting the rotor, voltage pick-up coils for sensing induced voltages, and skew pick-up coils for measuring flux build-up due to skew characteristics. The test head is retractable, allowing the operator to set up a rotor on an unused fixture during the test sequence. The apparatus includes a data acquisition, processing, and control system that controls the testing process, acquires data, and processes the data to determine rotor characteristics. The system also stores statistical data for analysis over multiple tests. The test sequence involves retracting the rotor, rotating it, and sampling voltage, current, and skew signals during the rotation. The data is processed to calculate resistance, reactance, and skew, and the results are displayed and printed.

The text describes a system and method for securing a computing device, particularly a mobile device, by implementing an arbitration layer that selectively grants access to native resources based on digital certificates associated with managed libraries and applications. The system includes a manager that validates digital certificates for managed libraries, allowing them access to native resources, while denying managed applications access to native resources unless their certificates authorize such access. The manager ensures that only approved managed libraries can be called by managed applications, thus protecting the device from malicious code. The system also includes a runtime host that executes native instructions, providing a secure interface between managed applications and the operating system. The text outlines various operational procedures for securing the device, including validating digital signatures, loading managed libraries and applications, and authorizing access to native resources.

The text describes an improved identification card design that incorporates an internal antenna and integrated circuit chip between two protective, non-rigid layers, allowing for printing of artwork. This structure is then laminated between two rigid outer layers for added protection. The card is made from a silica-filled polyolefin core, with an antenna and chip attached to the core's surface. The chip is secured with a special adhesive, and the entire structure is protected by two rigid outer layers. The card is designed to be more durable and easier to manufacture than previous smart card designs, which often used rigid materials and glue. The new design uses a lamination process that spreads external forces over compliant layers, protecting the delicate electronic components. The card is prepared by pre-shrinking the core layer, printing indicia and spids, attaching the antenna and chip, bonding the core layer to a bottom sheet, and then laminating the structure with protective layers. The card can be personalized with additional printing or inkjet coating before final lamination.

The present invention relates to the implementation of a queue, particularly a FIFO-type queue, in a memory. The solution is intended for use specifically in connection with functional memories, where updates are carried out by copying the path from the root of a tree-shaped structure to the point of updating, and then making the update in the copied data. The invention provides a novel way of establishing a queue by implementing and maintaining it with a tree-shaped structure in which nodes have a given maximum size. Additions of data units to the queue are directed to the first non-full node on the first edge of the data structure, and deletions are directed to a leaf node on the opposite edge. The tree-shaped data structure allows each update in the functional environment to require a time and space that are logarithmically dependent on the length of the queue. The invention also includes a preferred embodiment with a header node that contains three elements, each of which may be empty or contain a pointer, and a separate inversion bit to indicate the direction of the queue. The queue can be inverted in constant time and space, and the structure is fully symmetrical, allowing it to be used as a double-ended queue. The invention also includes a block diagram of a memory arrangement implementing the queue with a header node.

The text discusses the development of embedded EPROM devices that can be manufactured using existing integrated circuit (IC) technologies. Current EPROM devices are made with specialized technologies, making it impractical to include them alongside other ICs like DRAM or high-performance logic circuits on the same wafer. However, programmable redundancy circuits in DRAM devices are crucial for improving yield and reducing costs. The text proposes using EPROM devices instead of fuses for these circuits, as fuses occupy large areas and require complex, destructive programming. Additionally, EPROM devices are useful for applications like programmable firmware and product identification. The main challenge is that current EPROM devices cannot be made using standard logic technologies. The invention aims to provide practical methods for building embedded EPROM devices using existing IC manufacturing processes. This would enable the integration of EPROM devices with DRAM and logic circuits, reducing costs and improving functionality. The text also introduces stress EPROM devices, which use changes in transistor properties under stress conditions to store data, offering a solution for embedded applications. These devices can be manufactured using standard logic technologies, making them ideal for security and other applications where data is not detectable by physical analysis.

The invention relates to a technique for easily and quickly determining the optimum value of feedback gain used for calculating correction amount in feedback control. The method involves executing feedback control using a provisionally determined feedback gain, detecting an error between a designated value and an actual value of the subject of control, calculating an evaluation value indicative of the character of feedback control according to the detected error, executing the feedback control repeatedly after provisionally determining a new feedback gain value, and calculating a feedback gain value that can provide for a suitable evaluation value according to the relation between the feedback gain value and the evaluation value obtained. The method allows for the determination of a feedback gain that can realize a suitable feedback control characteristic quickly and reliably. The evaluation functions for the proportional, integral, and differential gains are used to determine the optimum values of these gains, respectively. The invention is applicable to various subjects of control, not limited to the running control of an AGV.

The text describes a zoom lens designed for photographic and video cameras, focusing on achieving a high relative aperture, a high zoom ratio, and a standard image angle at the wide angle end, while minimizing the size of the entire lens system. The lens is composed of five units, with specific conditions set for the focal lengths, radii of curvature, and Abbe numbers of the lenses to ensure high optical performance throughout the zooming range. The conditions include refractive power ratios for the fourth and fifth lens units, the focal length ratio of the second lens unit to the shortest focal length of the entire system, and the Abbe numbers of the first and sixth lenses in the fifth unit. The text also mentions that the fourth and fifth lens units are designed to correct residual aberrations effectively. Four numerical examples are provided to illustrate the construction of the zoom lens according to the invention.

The text describes a method and device for detecting elementary particles, such as protons, ions, electrons, neutrons, and photons. The method involves generating a charge pulse in the detector when a particle passes through it, converting the pulse into an electric signal, and indicating or recording the signal, either after amplification or integration. The device includes a detector for generating charge pulses, at least one fast amplifier for amplifying individual signals, and optionally a slow amplifier for integrating signals. The invention aims to provide a method and device that can detect individual particles and integrate signals, without needing to know the expected signal rates in advance. This is achieved by discharging the charge pulse on the low-voltage side of the detector, which simplifies the detection of small signals and prevents leakage currents. The device can separate signals based on their rate, allowing for the detection of individual particles and the integration of multiple signals, depending on the signal rate.

The invention relates to an apparatus for automatically spin checking driven disc assemblies used in friction clutches. The apparatus includes an enclosure with a stationary ring, a movable ring, and a torque motor with an output shaft connected to a splined hub. The driven disc assembly is mounted on the hub and frictionally engaged between the two rings. The movable ring is moved away from the stationary ring, reducing friction and allowing the torque motor to rotate the disc assembly. The distance between the rings is measured before and after rotation, and the difference is compared to a standard value to determine if the disc assembly is within acceptable tolerances. The apparatus automatically determines if the assembly is good or bad and generates an external indication to the operator. This improves efficiency and reduces operator error in the production environment.

The text describes a method for estimating the age of a person represented in an image. It involves using a contourlet appearance model (CAM) algorithm to extract feature vectors from the image, classifying the subject as younger or older, and then applying an appropriate aging function to estimate the age. The method can be implemented in a face age-estimation system, which can be a computer or a network of computers. The system uses a database of landmarked faces with known ages to train the model. The CAM algorithm is used to extract features that encode age information, and it is robust against noise. The system can handle issues like side views or tilted faces. The method includes steps for correcting lighting, applying a contourlet transform, and using principal component analysis. Support vector machines are used to build an age classifier and aging functions. The system can provide an estimated age as a single value or a set of values with confidence factors. The method can be implemented on a computing system, which includes a processor, memory, storage, input/output devices, and network interfaces.

The text describes a matrix display device for displaying two merged images, with the aim of preserving the higher definition image. The device comprises a matrix of pixels organized in a mosaic of identical arrangements, where some pixels are dedicated to the first image and others to the second. The two images can be redimensioned by scaling means. The device can be configured to apply an attenuation function to the light intensity signals of the first image when the signals for the second image exceed a threshold value, to preserve the definition of the higher quality image. The remaining pixels can display two colors that combine to restore the color of the first image. The controller can also apply values derived from a combination of the first image's light intensity signals to the second image's pixels when the second image's signals are below a threshold. The device can be used in various applications, such as displaying a high-definition image merged with a lower-definition image or a symbology image.

The text describes a mobile identification transmitter designed for activating a security system in a motor vehicle, with an added feature of a removable payment element for various payment actions. The transmitter has a housing with a receptacle for the payment element, which can be set in a normal state or a secure state. In the normal state, the payment element can communicate with a payment system, enabling payment transactions, while in the secure state, the payment element is removed, blocking payment actions but allowing communication with the vehicle's security system. The transmitter also includes an energy storage device to power the electronics and the payment element, and a closure to protect the receptacle and ensure the security of the payment element.

The text describes an imaging device, such as a xerographic machine, that becomes inactive when not in use. When the device is inactive for a long period, the tribo-electro-static charge of the toner may decrease, affecting image quality. To address this, the disclosed embodiments propose methods and apparatuses for charging the toner to a predetermined level based on the device's periods of inactivity. These methods involve determining the inactivity periods, measuring the toner charge level upon recovery, and adjusting the toner charge to a predetermined level. The intelligent toner charging system can predict the next user usage, calculate the decay of the tribo charge, and update the user usage pattern for future adjustments.

The present invention relates to an apparatus capable of controlling with high precision the recording and reproduction of signals by plural heads, particularly to a recording/reproducing apparatus in which a recording/regenerative integrated circuit with plural magneto resistive heads (MR heads) can be controlled with high precision. The invention further relates to an apparatus for reproducing digital information signals or the like with MR heads, and more particularly to a rotary magnetic head type apparatus in which bias currents to MR heads mounted on a rotary drum can be appropriately controlled.

The invention is about locating and tracing concealed elongated conductive objects like pipes or cables, especially when two objects are adjacent. It addresses the issue of difficulty in tracing a desired cable when another cable is present nearby. The system uses a transmitter with two distinguishable antennae to induce currents in the objects, and a receiver that senses both magnetic fields associated with these currents to produce an output signal dependent on both fields. This allows for easier and more accurate tracing of one object in the presence of another. The transmitting antennae are optimally positioned relative to the objects, and the currents can be distinguished using techniques like different carrier frequencies, amplitude modulation, or pulse repetition rates. The receiver processes the signals to produce a pulsating output that is easier to interpret than a steady tone. The system is particularly useful when the horizontal separation between the cables is related to the depth of the cable to be located. The invention enhances the performance of the receiver and reduces the induction of currents in the same cable when the transmitter is properly positioned.

The text describes an apparatus for interfacing a speaker phone with a telephone network to enable hands-free automatic answering and communication. It includes a source of power, a selector switch for connecting the apparatus to the network, and a timer to control the duration of the connection. The apparatus can be used to provide automatic answering capability for speaker phones, particularly advantageous for the physically handicapped or during convalescence. Two embodiments are discussed: one using an optocoupler to detect the telephone ringing signal and another using a neon lamp optically coupled with a photocell to automatically couple the speaker phone to the telephone lines.

The present invention relates to a system for reducing or eliminating undersea optical repeaters in a trunk and branch ring network by replacing repeaters with remotely pumped optical amplifiers and remotely supplying energy to those amplifiers over the same branch cables that distribute communications signals. The system includes an optical fiber cable trunk configured in a ring topology with one or more telecommunications hubs and branching units. The hubs are access points to the trunk, while the branching units allow for convenient add/drop points for telecommunications traffic. The invention utilizes the branch fiber optic cables, which also transmit communications signals, to unidirectionally transmit optical energy at a wavelength other than that of the signal wavelength. This energy is used as a power source for an optical amplifier, which is located in the branch fiber optic cable, the optical fiber cable trunk, or the branching unit, providing signal amplification without the use of conventional optical repeaters. The combination of hub assemblies, cable stations, and branch fiber optic cables allows for full connectivity along the trunk and to all cable stations via their respective branch fiber optic cables, even in the event of a trunk cut. Branch fiber optic cable cuts isolate the associated cable station without compromising ring integrity.
