The Welsh Government has been working closely with higher and further education institutions to prepare for Brexit, including visiting individual institutions to assess their readiness for a no-deal scenario. The Welsh Government has been refining its approach based on the evolving situation and the changing debate in both London and Europe.

The Welsh Government has been working closely with higher and further education institutions since the Brexit vote in 2016 to understand the potential impacts and prepare accordingly. The Cabinet Secretary for Education and the Minister for Welsh Language and Lifelong Learning, along with officials, have been monitoring the situation closely, visiting institutions, and refining their approach as the situation has evolved. The Higher Education Funding Council for Wales has also conducted specific work on the issue. The European transition team within Welsh Government provides governance and coordination across departments on European transition issues. The student voice, represented by the National Union of Students, has been engaged regularly and there is a consensus on the importance of maintaining open institutions, valuing faculty, continuing participation in Horizon 2020, and securing post-study work visas. The Welsh Government is concerned about the potential impact on FE colleges, particularly in relation to ESF funding and apprenticeships. The European transition team meets fortnightly to ensure Welsh Government is prepared for Brexit. The Welsh Government has been working with HEFCW to mitigate the impact of Brexit on the sector, including through the Global Wales initiative to boost international marketing. The Welsh Government is committed to implementing the Diamond and Reid reviews, which aim to make the funding of higher education more sustainable.

The Welsh Government is working closely with higher and further education institutions to prepare for Brexit, focusing on issues like student recruitment, funding, and European funding. The Welsh Government is committed to implementing the Diamond and Reid reviews for higher education, aiming for a sustainable funding model, and is exploring ways to support institutions in maintaining learning opportunities under new funding scenarios.

<summary>
The Welsh Government is preparing for Brexit's impact on higher and further education. The Cabinet Secretary for Education, Kirsty Williams, and Minister for Welsh Language and Lifelong Learning, Eluned Morgan, have outlined the sector's preparedness, particularly in relation to student recruitment, funding, and European funding. The government has been working closely with higher education institutions and further education colleges to understand their specific needs and challenges. There is a consensus across the government, institutions, and students on the importance of maintaining open borders for EU and international students, valuing faculty from the EU, and continuing participation in Horizon 2020 and Erasmus+ programs. The Welsh Government has been pushing for a deal with the UK government to ensure that international students are not included in immigration targets. The European transition team within the Welsh Government is coordinating with other departments to mitigate the impact of Brexit. The government has been engaging with the FE sector, which is less exposed to EU students, focusing on skills shortages and regional partnerships with employers. The Welsh Government has been working on a policy for rural skills and is considering the impact of Brexit on the economy and health sectors. The government has provided additional funding to HEFCW to deal with demographic changes and the initial implications of Brexit. The Welsh Government has allocated £6.4 million to HEFCW to address the short-term implications of Brexit and demographic changes. The government is also considering multi-year funding settlements for HE and FE to provide stability and security. The team evaluated the prototype of a remote control, considering aspects like design, functionality, and cost. The team also discussed the corporate identity and the possibility of changing the button shapes to maintain a fashionable appearance while staying within the budget.

The group discussed the design of a single-function television remote control, deciding on a simplistic design with glow-in-the-dark or light-up buttons for visibility, and considering an alarm system to help users locate the remote. They also explored the possibility of interchangeable faceplates to increase the product's popularity and profitability. The group agreed to further investigate the environmental impact of the design, including the use of shape-memory alloys for easy disassembly and recycling.

The group discussed the components design for a new remote control. The user interface designer suggested a simple design with a flip screen to prevent accidental button presses and a battery life indicator. Marketing emphasized the importance of an easy-to-use design, trendy features, and the willingness of consumers to pay for innovative technology. The group agreed on a wooden case, a simple design, and the possibility of a display. The user interface designer was tasked with creating a prototype, and the industrial designer was asked to find the cost of adding a display. The project manager outlined the next steps, including creating a marketing strategy and submitting the design to management.

The meeting discussed the conceptual design of a new remote control, focusing on components, functionality, and user interface. The team decided on a wooden case as the design material due to its environmental friendliness and potential for customization. The interface was simplified to include essential functions like on/off, volume, channel control, and menu access, with considerations for ergonomics and user-friendliness. The group agreed to proceed with a simple design without a display, but agreed to investigate the cost and utility of adding a display for future consideration.

The meeting was about summarizing the previous meeting's decisions and discussing the concept design for a new remote control. The team decided on a simple interface with a wheel for channel changes, protected buttons, volume control, and a power button. They also agreed to include a light feature for easy finding and decided against L_C_D_ and voice features for cost reasons. The industrial designer presented on the standard components needed, including a wheel sensor which was found to be more expensive than push buttons. The user interface designer suggested using a voice recognition chip already developed by the manufacturing division, which could be adapted for command recognition. The marketing expert discussed trends in fashion, suggesting the remote control should have a fancy, technological look and be easy to use. The team decided to keep the wheel and use a banana shape for the remote control, which would be both ergonomic and easy to find. The team is discussing the design and implementation of a system for collecting data on tourist activities in Heidelberg. They aim to create a belief network that will help the system make decisions based on user input. The network will consider factors like user preferences, budget, and the type of activity (e.g., sightseeing, meeting people, running errands). The team plans to collect data from 30-50 subjects, with each participant choosing three tasks from a list of tourist activities. The tasks include visiting places like the zoo, university, castle, or doing business. The team also discusses the need for a hierarchical structure in the tasks, allowing for more complex planning scenarios. They consider the importance of temporal references and the potential for redundancy in the data. The team agrees to collect data from ten subjects within two weeks and review the results. They plan to focus on eliciting specific semantic constructions during the data collection process, aiming for a first cut at several constructions to understand their interactions. The team also discusses the possibility of creating ideal speaker utterances to showcase the system's capabilities.

The meeting focused on planning the data collection for a system designed to assist tourists. The group discussed the structure of the data collection, aiming to gather information on tourist activities, preferences, and intentions. They considered creating a hierarchical system of activities, such as "go to place" with subcategories like "zoo" or "castle," to simplify the data. The team debated the complexity of the data, deciding to start with simpler scenarios and gradually increase complexity based on the data collected. They also discussed the importance of collecting data on temporal references and the need for a planner to help users schedule their activities over multiple days. The group agreed to collect data from ten subjects within two weeks and review the collected data in a meeting on the following Monday. They planned to transcribe some of the data to identify interesting patterns and potential areas for improvement in the system. The team also discussed the creation of a belief-net to make decisions based on user input and the collection of data on different constructions and sentence types to enhance the system's linguistic capabilities. Lastly, they outlined the steps for the summer, including building a belief-net, collecting data, and analyzing the data to improve the system's performance.

The team is introduced to the project of designing a new remote control for a television set, with the goal of creating a product that is original, trendy, and user-friendly. The project will be divided into three phases: functional design, technical design, and user interface design. The team members are assigned specific roles, with the marketing expert tasked with staying updated on the latest trends and user needs, the user interface designer focusing on the technical aspects from a user perspective, and the industrial designer addressing the internal workings, materials, and appearance of the product. The team begins the meeting by introducing themselves and sharing their favorite animals using the electronic whiteboard, symbolizing the freedom, efficiency, and teamwork they aim to incorporate into the remote control design.

The team discusses incorporating voice recognition into the new remote control design. Marketing suggests voice recognition could be appealing to younger audiences willing to pay extra for it. However, concerns are raised about the practicality of voice recognition, such as the need for training, potential user frustration with repetitive commands, and issues with regional accents. The team decides to focus on a user-focused design with a joystick and L_C_D. The joystick will handle basic functions like channel and volume control, while the L_C_D. will allow for more complex menu navigation. The team also considers adding a feature to locate the remote control if it's lost. The design will include a minimalist approach with a small joystick, L_C_D., and a button to access menus. The team plans to look into the feasibility of these features and the overall design. The slogan "We put the fashion in electronics" is considered for the remote control. The meeting concludes with the team agreeing on the design direction and next steps.

The meeting was about discussing the conceptual design of a new remote control, focusing on its components, design, and target market. The team agreed on the importance of a fancy design, easy usability, and innovative features. They decided to target the elderly market, with preferences for dark colors, recognisable shapes, and familiar materials like wood. The user interface was designed to be simple, with a focus on primary functions like sound control and channel shifting, and the inclusion of a small display. The energy source was decided to be a simple battery, with a docking station for charging, instead of kinetic energy. The case design would be single curved, and the interface would include buttons for easy channel and volume control, with the display placed on top for better visibility. The team also discussed the possibility of changeable case covers to attract a wider audience.

The team discusses the production finance for their remote control design. They aim to ensure the design fits within a budget of €12.50. The team evaluates their design against criteria such as innovation, user-friendliness, and ease of use. They rate their design as a two out of seven on each criterion, indicating it is generally well-designed but has room for improvement. The team then calculates the production costs, which exceed the budget due to features like an LCD screen and microphone. To meet the budget, they decide to remove these features, focusing instead on a simpler design with a single curve and a regular scroll wheel. The team adjusts the design to fit within the budget, and they move on to a production evaluation, summarizing their design and its cost-effectiveness.

The Welsh Government is committed to ensuring that targeted funding, such as the Pupil Development Grant (PDG), is effectively used to improve educational outcomes for disadvantaged students. The grant is primarily used to support children eligible for free school meals, but it can also be applied to those who are more able and talented. The Welsh Government has appointed new PDG regional advisers to provide strategic guidance and ensure consistent practice across regions. There is ongoing discussion about the eligibility criteria for PDG, with some considering whether to adjust it to include adopted children or those who were previously looked after. The Welsh Government is also looking at ways to improve attendance and engagement, as well as reducing exclusions for children on free school meals. The impact of PDG on attainment has been mixed, with some schools showing significant improvement while others have not. The Welsh Government is working to understand why there was a widening of the attainment gap in 2017 and is developing new performance measures that are more sophisticated and take into account the progress of each individual child. The Welsh Government is also considering the role of PDG for looked-after children, with a focus on strategic deployment and capacity building. The Schools Challenge Cymru programme, which aimed to improve schools with the highest proportions of disadvantaged students, had mixed results. The Welsh Government is using lessons learned from the programme to inform its wider school improvement strategy, including the use of regional consortia for support.

The Welsh Government is committed to ensuring that the pupil development grant (PDG) is targeted appropriately and used effectively to improve educational outcomes for disadvantaged pupils. The grant is primarily used to support children eligible for free school meals, but it can also be used for those who are more able and talented, as well as for looked-after children and adopted children. The Welsh Government has appointed new PDG regional advisers to provide strategic advice on the use of the grant across regions. There is a focus on improving attendance and engagement with education, particularly for children with free school meals, as well as addressing the higher exclusion rates for these children. The impact of PDG on attainment has been mixed, with some schools showing significant improvement, while others have seen a widening of the attainment gap. The Welsh Government is working on developing new performance measures for schools that are more sophisticated and take into account the progress of each individual child.

The discussion centered on the targeted funding to improve educational outcomes, specifically the Pupil Development Grant (PDG). Kirsty Williams, the Cabinet Secretary for Education, acknowledged that the eligibility criteria for PDG, based on free school meals, might not perfectly identify students in need, but it is the best proxy available. The PDG is being used to target more able and talented students, as well as to address attendance and exclusions. However, there are concerns about the impact of PDG on exam performance, particularly for students eligible for free school meals. The Welsh Government is considering changes to the PDG, such as making it more flexible and responsive, and is evaluating the effectiveness of PDG for looked-after children and adopted students. The PDG is seen as a tool to support vulnerable learners, and there is a focus on improving school leadership and teacher quality to enhance educational outcomes. The Welsh Government is also considering whether to adjust the eligibility criteria for PDG to include students who have been looked after or adopted at any point. The impact of the PDG on looked-after children's attainment is disappointing, and the Welsh Government is working on a review to understand the reasons behind this. The Schools Challenge Cymru program, which aimed to improve struggling secondary schools, had mixed results, with some schools making progress while others did not. The Welsh Government is taking lessons from this program to improve its school improvement strategies, focusing on leadership, teacher quality, and collaborative working.

<summary>
The Welsh Government is committed to using the Pupil Development Grant (PDG) to improve educational outcomes for children eligible for free school meals. The grant is targeted at individual interventions for these children, as well as universal interventions that disproportionately benefit them. The PDG is also used to support more able and talented students, including those eligible for free school meals. The Welsh Government has appointed new PDG regional advisers to provide strategic guidance on the effective use of the grant. There is a focus on improving attendance and engagement, particularly for children with free school meals, through initiatives like a walking bus and staff outreach. The attainment gap between free school meal-eligible and non-eligible students has widened in recent years, but the Welsh Government is working to understand the reasons behind this and improve educational outcomes. The PDG for looked-after children has been regionalized to improve strategic deployment and impact. The Welsh Government is considering adjustments to eligibility criteria for PDG to include adopted children. The Schools Challenge Cymru program, which aimed to improve struggling secondary schools, had mixed results, with some schools making progress and others not. The Welsh Government has transitioned to a new system of school categorization to provide targeted support to schools in need, rather than a program focused on specific schools. The Welsh Government is committed to learning lessons from the Schools Challenge Cymru program and applying them to its wider school improvement agenda. The Welsh Government has engaged with a variety of stakeholders to gather feedback on the PDG and the Schools Challenge Cymru program, including the program director, Mel Ainscow. The Welsh Government is considering further engagement with Ainscow to better understand the lessons learned from the program. The Welsh Government is focused on improving educational outcomes for all children, including those eligible for free school meals, through targeted funding and strategic interventions.
</summary>

The Welsh Government is committed to improving educational outcomes for disadvantaged students through the targeted use of the Pupil Development Grant (PDG). The grant has been used to support a range of initiatives aimed at addressing the needs of students eligible for free school meals, including whole-school approaches to growth mindset and universal interventions that disproportionately benefit free-school-meal students. The PDG is also being used to support more able and talented students, particularly those eligible for free school meals, through targeted programs and experiences. The Welsh Government is working to ensure better consistency in PDG usage across schools through the appointment of regional PDG advisers and by encouraging the use of evidence-based interventions. However, there is ongoing work to improve the targeting and effectiveness of PDG, including exploring the use of alternative eligibility measures and considering changes to the annual allocation period.

The meeting summary discusses updates on ongoing projects. Grad B reports on the EDU project, mentioning that Fey's time with the team is almost over, and ten dialogues have been transcribed. They plan to involve psychology department students in more complex experiments, as they need to complete two experiments for graduation. Grad B also updates on the SmartKom project, stating that they've resolved issues with synthesis and are meeting with Johno to finalize the process. 

Grad D presents on the Probabilistic Relational Model (PRM) for the EDU project. They've simplified the model by removing decision nodes and created classes like user, site, time, and route. The PRM aims to reduce computational complexity by using intermediate nodes to represent dependencies between user, site, and time attributes. 

Professor F discusses the need to find an existing PRM interpreter, as they may not develop their own. They believe the PRM could help in decision-making processes, like evaluating site suitability and planning visits. 

Grad B compliments the PRM's visual clarity and suggests reviewing the details. They express interest in reading the write-up and asks about the PRM's compatibility with the original model. 

Grad C introduces their project on content management systems, focusing on improving search engines by incorporating context information and user-specific interpretations. They plan to use a depth-first search approach to optimize search results based on user inputs. 

Professor F mentions the potential use of FrameNet in Grad C's project, suggesting it could help in keyword interpretation and document relevance. He also recommends connecting with other researchers at the Semantic Web Workshop for further collaboration.

<summary>
The Children, Young People and Education Committee scrutinized the 'Healthy Weight: Healthy Wales' draft strategy, focusing on its potential impact on children and young people. Dr Frank Atherton, the Chief Medical Officer for Wales, and Nathan Cook, the head of the healthy and active branch at Welsh Government, were questioned on the strategy's all-age approach, engagement with children, leadership, investment, and partnership working. Dr Atherton acknowledged the need for a target to reduce childhood obesity but emphasized the importance of balancing deliverability with challenge. The committee also discussed the potential use of sugar levy funds for obesity initiatives and the role of schools in promoting healthy environments. Lastly, the meeting concluded with a motion to exclude the public for the remainder of the discussion.
</summary>

<summary>
The Children, Young People and Education Committee is scrutinizing the 'Healthy Weight: Healthy Wales' draft strategy, with Dr Frank Atherton, Chief Medical Officer for Wales, and Nathan Cook, head of the healthy and active branch at Welsh Government, attending to answer questions. The strategy is an all-age plan, with a focus on addressing gaps in data and engaging children and young people. Dr Atherton acknowledges the need for a target to reduce childhood obesity, but suggests that the target should be challenging yet achievable. The Welsh Government is considering using the revenue from the levy on sugary soft drinks towards initiatives to tackle obesity. The strategy emphasizes partnership working across sectors, including education, health, and local government, to create healthy environments. The committee questions the Welsh Government's approach to data collection and the potential for legislation, such as restricting price promotions and banning energy drinks. The draft plan also includes a review of the clinical obesity pathway for children and young people. Lastly, the committee discusses the importance of making every contact count and the need for better availability of people to refer to for support in addressing weight issues. </summary>

The meeting discussed issues with using PDAs for recording, focusing on the impact of room noise and reverberation on audio quality. It was noted that the PDAs pick up significant room noise, particularly at lower frequencies, which can affect the clarity of the recordings. The team considered changing the input box's capacitor or applying a digital filter to mitigate this issue, but decided against it due to potential complications and the existing data collected. The team also discussed the importance of using high-pass filters in software like Feacalc to reduce the impact of room noise. The meeting also touched on the use of spectral subtraction for noise reduction, with mixed results, and the need for better voice activity detection. The group considered the benefits of integrating different spectral subtraction methods and the potential for improving speech recognition by enhancing the distinction between speech and noise. The team also discussed the use of a better voice activity detector and the possibility of using voiced-unvoiced detection to improve speech recognition in noisy environments.

The team discussed the merits and demerits of existing remote controls during a meeting. The project manager presented the minutes of the last meeting and asked if there were any questions. The marketing team shared their findings on market trends, emphasizing the importance of design, technology, and ease of use. The user interface designer presented existing remote control designs, highlighting flaws and innovative features. The industrial designer discussed the components of a remote control, focusing on the processor, amplifier, and transmitter. The team decided on a plastic and latex casing with a yellow color scheme and multi-colored buttons. They considered ergonomic shapes like a banana or gourd, but ultimately opted for a more abstract fruit-like design. The team agreed on a rechargeable battery and a speech recognition feature. The project manager concluded the meeting by assigning the task of creating a clay model to the team.

The meeting summary discusses various topics related to speech processing and recognition. PhD B presents on Wiener filtering, noting that a single-stage Wiener filter did not significantly improve performance over a baseline system. Adding a second stage of Wiener filtering, with smoothing, improved performance to 56.5% on the SpeechDat-Car dataset. Using the VAD output from channel zero instead of channel one also improved results. PhD D discusses spectral subtraction, using an overestimation factor to estimate noise and subtract it from the signal. This was applied in the power spectrum, with a threshold and noise addition to prevent negative values. Nonlinear smoothing was applied to the gain trajectory to reduce musical noise. This method improved performance on Italian but not Finnish. Professor C discusses the potential of smoothing techniques and the impact of negative values in the power spectrum. The meeting also touches on the use of smoothing in the time domain to reduce musical noise.

The meeting discusses the results of a wizard test data test involving a subject named Litonya. The team identifies issues with the reading task's length and the introduction of the wizard. They plan to refine the tasks and switch tasks between subjects to improve data collection. The team also discusses the possibility of hiring Fey to manage subjects and organize data. The group agrees to present the project to linguists on Wednesday, focusing on both computer science and linguistic aspects. The team presents a pedagogical belief net designed to categorize information based on image schemas like Trajector-landmark and Source-path-goal. The group discusses the need to simplify the belief net to avoid a combinatorial explosion and the importance of gathering relevant information from various sources like the ontology, dialogue history, and the real world.

The team also plans to develop a docking station for the remote, aiming for a fruity, spongy design with trendy colors. The text is a transcript of a meeting where Professor B discusses the Aurora project, a speech recognition initiative. The group is working on improving recognition in noisy environments. The meeting also touches on the possibility of using noise addition or subtraction to improve recognition in noisy speech. The group is also experimenting with the critical band spectrum and the TRAP recognition method. The Aurora evaluation is scheduled for June, but the baseline criteria are still under discussion. The team is looking into ways to optimize the recognition system, including adjusting feature vector exponents, to improve performance.

The Higher Education Funding Council for Wales, led by Dr. David Blaney, provided evidence on the impact of Brexit on Welsh higher education. They noted that the sector is facing pressures, including a decrease in EU student applications and recruitment, which could be linked to Brexit. The funding position is a major pressure, with the implementation of Sir Ian Diamond's recommendations for funding higher education still pending. The sector is trying to minimize cost reductions while maintaining infrastructure to prepare for future funding. The uncertainty around Brexit's impact on EU funding, research collaborations, and student mobility is a concern. Universities are planning for various scenarios, including potential changes to Erasmus+ funding. The sector is also working on promoting Wales as an attractive study destination and seeking additional sources of funding. The committee discussed the importance of clarity on funding and the potential impact of Brexit on research funding and international mobility.

The Higher Education Funding Council for Wales, led by Dr. David Blaney, has observed a decrease in EU student applications to Welsh universities, with a 8% drop compared to a 2% increase in English institutions. This is partly attributed to changes in student support arrangements for EU students, who now have to pay full fees instead of receiving grants. The sector is also facing pressures from reduced funding, student recruitment, pay and pension costs, and the uncertainty surrounding the implications of the Augar review on fees and funding. The institutions are preparing for various Brexit scenarios, with a focus on maintaining infrastructure and resources in the short term, and are looking to diversify funding sources and improve marketing strategies to attract students.

The Higher Education Funding Council for Wales (HEFCW) has provided evidence on the impact of Brexit on Welsh higher education. The main pressures on the sector are funding, student recruitment, pay and pension costs, capital expenditure, and uncertainty around the implications of Brexit. EU student applications to Welsh institutions have decreased by 8% compared to a 2% increase in England. The change in student support arrangements for EU students is seen as a factor, but so is the attractiveness of the institutions' estates and environments. The HE sector is facing financial challenges, with a managed deficit, and is preparing for Brexit by exploring scenarios and seeking additional funding sources. The Welsh Government is part of a HE Brexit working group, and institutions are advised to plan for various Brexit outcomes. The sector is also focusing on promoting Wales as an international study destination and maintaining research funding. The HEFCW has a role in monitoring institutions' financial sustainability and ensuring they are aware of the risks. The committee is concerned about the lack of clarity on funding from the Welsh Government and the potential impact on universities. The HEFCW is working with institutions to ensure they are prepared for Brexit and are aware of the potential risks.

The Higher Education Funding Council for Wales (HEFCW) has provided evidence on the potential impacts of Brexit on Welsh higher education. The sector is facing challenges due to uncertainty around funding, particularly in relation to EU student recruitment and EU research funding. EU student applications to Welsh institutions have decreased by 8% compared to a 2% increase in England. The change in student support arrangements for EU students is seen as a factor, but so is the attractiveness of institutions' facilities and estates. The HE sector is also facing pressures from reduced funding, pay and pension costs, and increased student expectations for modern facilities. The HEFCW is monitoring institutions' financial forecasts and scenarios, and is advising them to plan for various Brexit outcomes. The sector is working on initiatives to promote Wales as an attractive study destination, such as the 'Study in Wales' campaign. The HEFCW is also consulting on using international mobility as a performance indicator in fee and access plans. The sector is committed to maintaining student mobility opportunities, including through alternative programmes if Erasmus+ funding is not available. The HEFCW has a memorandum of understanding with the National Union of Students in Wales and requires providers to have student charters to protect student interests. The uncertainty around Brexit funding and the future of EU student recruitment is a concern for the sector. The HEFCW is advising the Welsh Government on the potential need for transition funding to support the sector through the Brexit process. The Welsh Government has commissioned a report on supporting research and innovation in the transition period, which builds on the Diamond recommendations. The HE sector is also facing challenges in gaining funding from UK research councils, which are linked to investment levels and engagement with research councils. The Ser Cymru II initiative has been successful in attracting key research players and fostering industry collaboration.

The committee is conducting an inquiry into the status of the Welsh baccalaureate qualification. The Cabinet Secretary for Education, Kirsty Williams, and her colleagues were questioned about the value of the qualification for learners and teachers. Williams stated that she values the qualification for its role in providing a broad and balanced curriculum, preparing students for further study and the workforce. She mentioned that the qualification has been positively received by many students and has been used successfully to gain university places. However, there have been concerns raised about workload issues, the variability in its delivery, and the inconsistency in understanding its value among employers. The Welsh Government is addressing these issues through a review by Qualifications Wales, professional learning opportunities for teachers, and performance measures for schools. The Cabinet Secretary also discussed the importance of leadership in schools and the need for better communication with employers to improve understanding of the qualification. Universities generally value the qualification, but there is some inconsistency in how they use it for admissions. The Welsh Government is working to ensure universal adoption of the qualification, with support for schools and colleges to deliver it effectively. The committee also discussed concerns about the impact on the curriculum and the emotional health of students. The Cabinet Secretary acknowledged the stress that studying A-levels can cause and the importance of providing support to students during this time.

The Children (Abolition of Defence of Reasonable Punishment) (Wales) Bill aims to prohibit physical punishment of children in Wales. The Welsh Government has received mixed responses to the Bill, with some 70% of individuals who responded to the written consultation opposing it. The Deputy Minister for Health and Social Services, Julie Morgan AM, argues that the Bill is necessary to protect children's rights and ensure they have the same protection from physical punishment as adults. The Bill is part of a wider package of support for children and parents, including the 'Parenting. Give it time' campaign and universal services provided by local government, health, education, social services, social justice, and the third sector. The Welsh Government is also conducting a mapping exercise to identify gaps in parenting support and to ensure that there are no unmet needs. The Bill's implementation will involve an awareness-raising campaign, and the Welsh Government is committed to this, although the Deputy Minister is open to considering putting a duty to raise awareness on the face of the Bill. The Welsh Government is also working with agencies such as the police, the Crown Prosecution Service, and the Association of Directors of Social Services Cymru to prepare for the Bill's implementation. The Deputy Minister acknowledges that there may be some unknown costs associated with the Bill, but the Government is working to mitigate these risks and ensure that the Bill is implemented in a practical and workable way.
</summary>

<summary>
The Welsh Government has outlined principles for reopening schools, which will be guided by the health and well-being of students and staff, the wider Welsh Government response to the pandemic, clear communication, prioritizing certain groups, and operational considerations. These principles apply to both schools and further education colleges, but universities, as independent institutions, cannot be dictated to. The Welsh Government is working with representatives of the higher education sector to include them in planning. The current focus is on maintaining hubs for vulnerable children and those of key workers, with an increase in attendance since the start of the traditional summer term. The smooth operation of these hubs is prioritized, and there have been 15 reported cases of teachers being tested for COVID-19, with 2 positive results. The ability to test, trace, and quarantine will be crucial in the next phase of the pandemic response. Vulnerable children are being risk-assessed and supported by local authorities and schools, with some children attending hubs and others receiving support in other ways. The Welsh Government has allocated £1.25 million to provide school counseling services, which can be delivered remotely. The education system is also focusing on the mental health and well-being of students, providing resources and support through the Hwb digital learning platform. The Welsh Government is working with local authorities to ensure all children have access to the necessary hardware and connectivity for digital learning. Parents are being encouraged to engage with their child's school for guidance on supporting their child's education at home. The Welsh Government is also providing resources and courses through Hwb for year 13 and 12 students to prepare for further education and to support students in higher education. The moratorium on unconditional university offers is still in place until 1 May, and the Welsh Government is in ongoing discussions with the UK government and other nations to support students during this challenging time. </summary>

The Children (Abolition of Defence of Reasonable Punishment) (Wales) Bill aims to remove the legal defense of reasonable punishment for parents in Wales. The Association of Directors of Social Services (ADSS), the Association of Directors of Education Wales (ADEW), and the Welsh Local Government Association (WLGA) support the Bill, stating it aligns with the rights of the child as outlined in the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child. They argue that the current law is ineffective and unclear, and that removing the defense will bring clarity and better protect children. The groups emphasize the importance of awareness raising and training for professionals, as well as the need for resources and support for families. They also note that the impact on local authorities and social services is uncertain, but that they are committed to being involved in the implementation phase. The Bill is expected to peak in referrals and interventions initially, but settle over time. The groups are concerned about the potential for increased costs and the need for additional resources, particularly for preventative services.

The Children (Abolition of Defence of Reasonable Punishment) (Wales) Bill aims to clarify and strengthen the rights of children in Wales. Witnesses from the Association of Directors of Social Services, the Association of Directors of Education Wales, and the Welsh Local Government Association support the Bill, emphasizing the importance of upholding children's rights and the need for clarity in how children are cared for. They argue that the current law is ineffective and unclear, and that the Bill will improve children's positions within their families by removing the defense of reasonable punishment. The witnesses also highlight that physical punishment is harmful to children, as it is emotionally damaging and can lead to more serious forms of abuse. They acknowledge the need for resources and awareness-raising campaigns to support the implementation of the Bill, particularly in relation to training for professionals and support for families. The witnesses also discuss the potential impact on local authority services, such as social services and out-of-hours teams, and the importance of maintaining preventative services. The Bill's explanatory memorandum estimates that 274 offenses annually involve the use of lawful chastisement as a defense, and there may be an increased demand on out-of-hours services due to the time offenses are reported. The witnesses suggest that the Welsh Government should have a clear duty to raise awareness of the impact of the Bill. Finally, the committee resolves to exclude the public for the remainder of the meeting.

They also discussed the need for awareness-raising campaigns, training, and resources to support implementation, acknowledging the potential impact on local authority services and the importance of maintaining support for families.

The meeting discussed the progress of transcribing digit recordings and the possibility of reorganizing file names for easier sorting. The group considered changing the naming convention to include three letters and three numbers for meeting IDs, speaker IDs, and channel information. The transcribers are now working channel-by-channel to improve time bin accuracy, which is crucial for overlap analysis. The transcribers occasionally overlook backchannels in dense overlaps, and the team is considering using speech segmentation algorithms to address this issue.
